c6b9b71d1e2903d6fc2094c91560c855.summary: Eugene (Eugene/Yevhen/Zhenya) Vahin, 33, died after an unroped fall while ice climbing at The Junkyards near Grassi Lakes in the Bow Valley, Alberta. He was reported overdue on January 23; responders from Kananaskis Mountain Rescue and RCMP later located and recovered his body. According to his spouse, he was unroped and likely slipped near the top of a route after filming; his last GoPro video ended at 3:44 p.m.

people.name: Eugene Vahin
people.injuries: Severe head injury and internal bleeding (per medical examiners relayed to spouse).

timeline.description: Last GoPro video timestamp; standing near edge of ice with nearby ground/grass visible.
Spouse searched the area, slipped ~50 ft on steep icy slope but self-arrested on a tree; then called emergency services.
Same evening: RCMP and Kananaskis Mountain Rescue located and recovered the body.

events.description: Climbing unroped near the top of an ice route while filming.
Unroped slip/fall; incident not captured on camera.
Kananaskis Mountain Rescue and RCMP conducted body recovery.

rescue.method: Recovered by Kananaskis Mountain Rescue from terrain and transferred to RCMP.

gear_notes: Fall not captured on GoPro; last video stopped at 3:44 p.m.
One crampon was returned without a strap (cause unknown).

gear_condition_issues: one crampon returned without a strap (cause unknown)

uncertainties_list: Exact fall mechanism not captured on camera
Whether gear issues (e.g., missing crampon strap) contributed

cause_classification.narrative_summary: An unroped slip near the top of an ice route led to a fatal fall; familiarity with the home crag and beginner experience likely contributed.

other_source_statements.statement: Cause and fall distance not specified.

quoted_dialogue.quote: It seems to me that it was precisely the idea of this waterfall as ‘home’ and the easiest of all [the places] he climbed, that resulted in his fatal mistake.
quoted_dialogue.speaker: Ekaterina Shurko

quoted_dialogue.quote: From it you can see that he is standing on the edge of the ice, a meter away from him there is earth and grass. I suppose that this gave a false impression of safety.
quoted_dialogue.speaker: Ekaterina Shurko

b6568f214eaaada0b66f823c190752ee.title: Three Climbers Killed After 400-Foot Fall in Washington
b6568f214eaaada0b66f823c190752ee.accident_time_approx: around 5:30 p.m. retreat; fall during descent

people.name: Anton Tselykh
people.injuries: internal bleeding and traumatic brain injury; no broken bones reported

people.name: Vishnu Irigireddy
people.injuries: severe head (cranial) trauma and multiple leg fractures

people.name: Tim Nguyen
people.injuries: severe head (cranial) trauma and multiple leg fractures

people.name: Oleksander Martynenko
people.injuries: severe head (cranial) trauma and multiple leg fractures

b6568f214eaaada0b66f823c190752ee.rescue_method: Survivor self-evacuated on foot to vehicle and drove to seek help; bodies recovered by helicopter
b6568f214eaaada0b66f823c190752ee.response_difficulties: Survivor disoriented after head injury; darkness; incorrect direction of travel to seek help; vehicle struck a guardrail en route
b6568f214eaaada0b66f823c190752ee.accident_summary_text: A party of four retreated from Early Winter Couloir on the Early Winters Spires as weather approached. During the rappel descent, a single, very weathered piton reportedly failed, causing a ~200 ft fall followed by another ~200 ft tumble. Three climbers died of severe trauma. The lone survivor, Anton Tselykh, sustained internal bleeding and traumatic brain injury, self-evacuated in the dark, and eventually reached help after driving west over the pass.
b6568f214eaaada0b66f823c190752ee.timeline_text: ≈5:30 p.m.: Team roughly halfway up 1,100-ft route notices a storm and decides to retreat. During the descent, the rappel anchor fails; all four fall ~200 ft and tumble another ~200 ft. The survivor loses consciousness and later wakes around 10 p.m., self-evacuates to his car in the dark, drives west over the Cascades (colliding with a guardrail en route) and ultimately reaches help. SAR later recovers the three bodies by helicopter.
quoted_dialogue: "It is truly amazing that he came out with the injuries that he did," — Undersheriff David Yarnell
"[Head trauma] may have led him to make some not-so-good decisions as he tried to self rescue." — Undersheriff David Yarnell
b6568f214eaaada0b66f823c190752ee.notable_equipment_details: Rappel line found attached to a single, very weathered piton that reportedly ripped from the rock; SAR found the piton still attached to the line. It is unclear if the anchor was backed up. All four were attached to the same rope. Survivor did not use GPS communication devices to call for help.

rope_system.failure_description: Anchor blew while rappelling; all four fell simultaneously.

rescue_and_outcome.survivor_condition_notes: Traumatic brain injury and internal bleeding; hospitalized; reported disorientation

uncertainties_list: Whether the rappel anchor was backed up is unknown
Exact anchor build and sequence of failure unknown
Precise timing of the fall unknown

cause_classification.narrative_summary: A weathered piton likely serving as a single-point rappel anchor failed during a late-day retreat amid incoming weather, causing a simultaneous group fall.

events.description: Team approximately halfway up Early Winter Couloir when weather moves in.
Team decides to retreat around 5:30 p.m. as a storm approaches.
All four attached to the same rope for descent.
Anchor failure causes ~200 ft fall and ~200 ft tumble.
Survivor regains consciousness near 10 p.m., hikes out in darkness to car, drives west over the pass seeking help.
Bodies recovered by Snohomish County helicopter rescue team.
